Comments_List: You work on all aspects of public speaking -- ultimately the class is focused more on the physical/vocal elements than the content (though you do get practice with speaking on different topics -- a speech to teach, a speech to initiate action, a speech to change an attitude, etc.). The class also had interesting discussions on the intersections of race and gender with communication.
learning to use hand gestures and have confidence in front of a group in addition to the different ways to prepare for a speech has improved my public speaking confidence.
Rhetorical strategies, the art of public speaking, academic analysis of public speaking etc.
public speaking techniques, different contexts of public speaking (gender, race, etc)
How to be a better communicator and speaker!
This class helped me to become a more confident speaker, both in a formal speech-giving setting as well as in interpersonal conversations and in class.
I learned to be aware of my body while speaking, how to incorporate gestures into speeches, and how to sound and look confident while delivering a speech.

I learned about my strengths and weaknesses as a public speaker, as well as tips and tricks for getting around unhelpful speaking habits. I also learned to push myself out of my comfort zone, time after time, by getting up and speaking in front of people. I also learned about Aristotle's logos, ethos, and pathos, and how to weave all three elements effectively into a speech.

I learned how to be a more confident public speaker, how to calm my nerves when in front of a crowd, and also more about myself and what my speaking quirks are. I learned what I am naturally good at and where there are areas for improvement.

Take this course!! This was the first semester THST 343 branched out into accepting more students and dividing the group into sections (which I was initially nervous about). However, my group still grew incredibly close over the course of the semester, and I truly think I've gained much more confidence in public speaking because of the class. Everyone in the class came from different levels of comfort/experience in public speaking, but were ultimately supportive, non-judgemental, and very helpful in providing constructive feedback.

I would definitely recommend this class to another student - I think it should be a mandatory requirement of all students. It teaches you the basics of public speaking while providing a forum to practice giving actual speeches - something that many students otherwise would not have.
Yes: I learned a lot in the course but I would not say it drastically improved my public speaking skills if you are coming in with experience.
